Yii Framework v2.0.0-dev Class Reference

Trait yii\db\QueryTrait

All Classes | Properties | Methods
Implemented byyii\db\ActiveQuery, yii\db\ActiveRelation, yii\db\Query, yii\redis\ActiveQuery, yii\redis\ActiveRelation
Available since version2.0
Source Code
The BaseQuery trait represents the minimum method set of a database Query.

It has support for getting \yii\db\one instance or \yii\db\all. Allows pagination via limit() and offset(). Sorting is supported via orderBy() and items can be limited to match some conditions unsing where().

By calling \yii\db\createCommand(), we can get a yii\db\Command instance which can be further used to perform/execute the DB query against a database.

Property Details

$where property
string|array $where = null

Query condition. This refers to the WHERE clause in a SQL statement. For example, age > 31 AND team = 1.

See Also

  • where()
$limit property
integer $limit = null

Maximum number of records to be returned. If not set or less than 0, it means no limit.

$offset property
integer $offset = null

Zero-based offset from where the records are to be returned. If not set or less than 0, it means starting from the beginning.

$orderBy property
array $orderBy = null

How to sort the query results. This is used to construct the ORDER BY clause in a SQL statement. The array keys are the columns to be sorted by, and the array values are the corresponding sort directions which can be either SORT_ASC or SORT_DESC. The array may also contain yii\db\Expression objects. If that is the case, the expressions will be converted into strings without any change.

$indexBy property
string|callable $indexBy = null

The name of the column by which the query results should be indexed by. This can also be a callable (e.g. anonymous function) that returns the index value based on the given row data. For more details, see indexBy(). This property is only used by \yii\db\all().

Method Details

indexBy() method
static indexBy( $column )
$column string|callable

The name of the column by which the query results should be indexed by. This can also be a callable (e.g. anonymous function) that returns the index value based on the given row data. The signature of the callable should be:

function ($row)
{
    // return the index value corresponding to $row
}
return static the query object itself

Sets the indexBy() property.

where() method
static where( $condition )
$condition array The conditions that should be put in the WHERE part.
return static the query object itself

Sets the WHERE part of the query.

See yii\db\QueryInterface::where() for detailed documentation.

See Also

  • andWhere()
  • orWhere()
andWhere() method
static andWhere( $condition )
$condition string|array The new WHERE condition. Please refer to where() on how to specify this parameter.
return static the query object itself

Adds an additional WHERE condition to the existing one.

The new condition and the existing one will be joined using the 'AND' operator.

See Also

  • where()
  • orWhere()
orWhere() method
static orWhere( $condition )
$condition string|array The new WHERE condition. Please refer to where() on how to specify this parameter.
return static the query object itself

Adds an additional WHERE condition to the existing one.

The new condition and the existing one will be joined using the 'OR' operator.

See Also

  • where()
  • andWhere()
orderBy() method
static orderBy( $columns )
$columns string|array The columns (and the directions) to be ordered by. Columns can be specified in either a string (e.g. "id ASC, name DESC") or an array (e.g. ['id' => SORT_ASC, 'name' => SORT_DESC]). The method will automatically quote the column names unless a column contains some parenthesis (which means the column contains a DB expression). Note that if your order-by is an expression containing commas, you should always use an array to represent the order-by information. Otherwise, the method will not be able to correctly determine the order-by columns.
return static the query object itself

Sets the ORDER BY part of the query.

See Also

  • addOrderBy()
addOrderBy() method
static addOrderBy( $columns )
$columns string|array The columns (and the directions) to be ordered by. Columns can be specified in either a string (e.g. "id ASC, name DESC") or an array (e.g. ['id' => SORT_ASC, 'name' => SORT_DESC]). The method will automatically quote the column names unless a column contains some parenthesis (which means the column contains a DB expression).
return static the query object itself

Adds additional ORDER BY columns to the query.

See Also

  • orderBy()

$columns

static limit( $limit )

Sets the LIMIT part of the query.

$offset integer The offset. Use null or negative value to disable offset.
